item.title: Ticket #3327 (Reorganizing language files and functions) created
item.dc:creator: pandem
item.description:
Just to take advantage of the changes proposed in #3315, it could be a good idea to centralize all language files in one folder. I'd do the same with TinyMCE js files if possible as this would be a great improvement for us translators, but it'd probably be a hassle for coders.

I know i18n of themes is not encouraged but, as the use of WordPress as CMS increases, also does the i18nalizing needs, therefore my proposal.

item.title: Ticket #2144 (linking error numbers to reference) closed
item.dc:creator: Nazgul
item.description:
wontfix:

Because it's only "developers and weekend hackers" that see mysql errors (and even they shouldn't be seeing them often), it's only a very small user group that would benefit from this addition.

And for those power users it's easy enough to just copy and past the error to Google, if they don't know what it means already.

Furthermore, we don't have any control whatsoever on the content on that site, so I'm not in favor of including links to it in core.

item.title: Ticket #2830 (Change the way t he domain is being retrieved for sending e-mails from ...) closed
item.dc:creator: Nazgul
item.description:
wontfix:

I agree with westi. I'd rather see this implemented as a plugin than cluttering the core with an option that only a small subset of the users will ever use.

I've taken westi's example one step further and added a configuration page to it, so you can set the email adres from the admin section. (The largly untested statement still stands though)

item.title: customsender.php attached to Ticket #2830
item.dc:creator: Nazgul
item.description: Plugin.

item.title: Ticket #2830 (Change the way t he domain is being retrieved for sending e-mails from ...) updated
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
Owner, Status changed

I don't think this needs to be a core feature.

A very simple plugin (untested but should work fine) can be used to replace the builtin wp_mail function with one that sends from another address: 

/*
   Plugin Name: Override Email Address
   Description: Allows you to override the email address used by wp_mail
   Author: Peter Westwood
   Version: 0.01
   Author URI: http://blog.ftwr.co.uk/
 */
function wp_mail($to, $subject, $message, $headers = '') {
	if( $headers == '' ) {
		$headers = "MIME-Version: 1.0\n" .
		"From: user@domain \n" .
		"Content-Type: text/plain; charset=\"" . get_settings('blog_charset') . "\"\n";
	}
	return @mail($to, $subject, $message, $headers);
}

Replacing user@domain in the above plugin and activating it will allow you to pick the email address you want the emails to originate from.

This plugin works because wp_mail is one of the pluggable functions that a plugin can override by defining it before WordPress

item.title: Ticket #3315 (Language files in wp-content) updated
item.dc:creator: idle
item.description:
In response to Ryan's comment:

Because future upgrades will overwrite the modified files, unless you want to manually update your files. Adding new files to wp-includes or wp-admin is a whole different arm, however.

Personally, I never delete my wp-includes directory, but keep my global functions in a file of its own inside that directory. Anyway, I like this patch. Nice work, Nazgul!
